Posts.Content: Ever heard stories about folks who checked their PSA's for a long period of time then failed to do so for a time, only to find there had been a recurrence? Well here I am. I was diagnosed in 2000 at 42, PSA 10, Gleason 7. Clean lab report. For 10 years until 2010 the PSA was 0.2 or lower, which my surgeon at the University of Michigan instructed me to use to define recurrence. I failed to check it since. Perhaps it became buried in the recesses of my mind or it was easier to assume it was okay. This year I had a physical, the doctor included a PSA, and to my shock it checked at 2.88. In retrospect, I shouldn't have been shocked. I'm sure you are amazed, exaspertated, incredulous at me. But I can assure you, no matter what negative emotion this raises in you, I have directed same at myself 100 times over. I am in therapy both for dealing with the disease and particularly for compromising my treatment. My primary referred me to a local uro whose plan was accepting the disease as systemic and moving to intermittent hormone therapy. I balked at giving up and moved back to the cancer center where a radiation oncologist said there was some possibilty, despite the PSA admittedly being VERY high for salvage. Based on my relatively young age of 57, he devised an agressive plan, radiation with two years of hormone therapy alongside. Obviously we won't know how successful we were for sometime until the hormone block is off. Apparently the research is showing ADT with radiation as effective and a long period afterward can help reduce the chance of a recurrence in the out years after it's over. The radiation oncologist also expects some form of ADT alongside salvage to become the standard. Given my age and how well tolerated radiation is now, I've undertaken the second option. I'm sure two years of hormone therapy will be tough but that was in my future either way. Fire away at me guys.
Posts.Title: I'm that guy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikeg IM- Has the doc suggested getting any scans? You may want to ask him about doing scans to see if the cancer has moved outside of the prostate bed. There are some newer scans out, Choline C-11 and Gallium 68, that you may want to consider before undergoing the radiation. Mike I called Mayo and they said minimum two month wait - where else might these be available?
Posts.Title: I'm that guy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ron_G Best of luck, guy. I hope your treatment plan works out for the best. While not an ideal situation, I don't believe anyone here is going to beat you up over the situation you've found yourself in and will instead offer you support. Hang in there! Ron Thanks, Ron. Seems like a great bunch of folks and probably why I felt safe telling my story here.

Posts.Title: I'm that guy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by white08gt My urologist wanted to keep me on the HT for 3 years, I opted out 3 months after SRT. Changed Urologists who gave me some options where the other did not. Kept a close eye on my PSA every 6 weeks while my testosterone was still very low, as it was creeping up changed to every 3 months. Now that my T is in the 400 range back to every 2 months. So far my PSA has been <0.05 which is as low as the lab reads for 1 year. Doc told me the affects of HT can be 6 months to a year, my T took about 4 months to start an upward trend from zero. I did not tolerate HT very well at all. Being active and keeping a workout log for the last 3 years at the fitness center, I could see my health and strength do a nose dive. Don't know when the time comes with a reoccurrence that I will go back on HT. With a G8 and staged at 3tb mu urologist said there is a 70% that it will pop back up. As with Inquiring Mind, I asked my doctor how can we tell if the SRT worked or is it HT keeping my psa undectable, inquiring mind want to know. Asked the same and answer was you don't. Have to wait until HT is over and find out.
Posts.Title: Two Years of HT alongside salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Against my better judegment I'm going to jinx things and say I had a 3 month shot of Lupron two weeks ago and so far have just felt short, mild, warm flashes. I have noticed myself irritable in a couple of situations but there were other factors as well, so not sure if that was the drug. My neck has been sore a couple of times, but again, that could be stress and was relieved by some Ibuprofen.
Posts.Title: How long before HT symptoms?

Posts.Content: Can anyone comment?
Posts.Title: Two Years of HT alongside salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikeg My MO told me that they use the Lupron to weaken the cells that are in there and hope that the radiation will be able to kill any weaker cells that are remaining when they beam the prostate bed. That explains doing it during, but what about two or three years down the road? Failing to see how that far out would prevent recurrence long term - it would only mask the PSA.
Posts.Title: Two Years of HT alongside salvage radiation

Posts.Content: A study showed survival rates were higher for salvage plus 2 years of HDT versus salvage plus placebo. https://www.astro.org/News-and-Media...pley_AM15.aspx But if you take two groups of men in any stage and treatment regimen of prostate cancer, and give one group a two year block and the other placebo to go with it, I'm pretty sure survival would be higher for the block group. I can't understand how HRT extended this far increases the chance of "cure" as most folks understand it.
Posts.Title: Two Years of HT alongside salvage radiation

Posts.Content: My only other thought is the hope that the two years, along with the radiation, contributes to an extended remission. For example, my surgery didn't "cure" me - my PSA eventaully rose and I require further treatment. But it did result in a 10-15 year remission. Had I not ever had it done, I'm pretty sure my outlook would be more ominous. So, while not curitve as hoped, it was a positive.
Posts.Signature: To the best of my recollection... Diagnosed fall 2000, age 42, PSA 10 Gleason 6 Surgery University of Michigan December 2000, Martin Sanda, lab report clean in all respects, organ confined, Gleason upgraded to 7 PSA 0.2 or less through 2010 (standard instructed by surgeon), gap in PSA testing until 2015, came in at 2.88. (I know, I know). Currently undergoing EBRT Dec 2015 and Jan 2016 with 2 years of adjunctive hormone therapy
Posts.Title: Two Years of HT alongside salvage radiation

Posts.Content: My doctor recommended this in my case and I have seen several others mention it as a strategy in cases with a high chance of recurrence. I find it a bit confusing since I understood HT only stunned or put to sleep the cells which were sensitive to it - and had no impact on some cells at all. Wouldn't the radiation have to kill the cancer cells to prevent recurrence long term? It seems continuing hormone therapy this long would simply mask PSA. How would continuing the HT so far out help permanently prevent recurrence?
Posts.Title: Two Years of HT alongside salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Fingers crossed this is as bad as it gets. Hopefully you are one of the fortunate ones. Not sure anyone accumulated enough data to determine % of men with mild, versus severe side effects. Then again I imagine what could be severe for one might be just inconvenient for another. Allen Posted this in the HT thread... Side effects of hormone therapy Common •hot flashes, which may subside with time •decreased libido •erectile dysfunction •gynecomastia (breast enlargement and tenderness; occurs only with certain types of hormone therapy) •osteoporosis (bone erosion that may cause fractures; only with long-term use) •weight gain, loss of muscle mass •fatigue, anemia •changes in blood cholesterol and blood glucose measurements Uncommon •depression, loss of mental “sharpness” •abnormalities of the liver and liver function test results Rare •aches and joint pains •changes in the heart’s electrical signals http://www.harvardprostateknowledge....rostate-cancer The loss of mental sharpness particularly concerns me as I am 57 and still have to work.
Posts.Title: How long before HT symptoms?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Marve I'd like to know same thing. My dad first shot was week ago. Right now no symphtoms. I hope it stays so Thought I read two weeks is average but "your mileage may vary".
Posts.Title: How long before HT symptoms?

Posts.Content: Hope no one minds a thread a little out there. Dealing with PCa can certainly cause anxiety, and a therapist recommended to me the old rubber band technique - simply wear one on your wrist and snap it whenever you are feeling anxious, having negative thoughts, etc. Trying it this morning and I have to say it works surprisingly well. We'll see if it stands the test of time. Mods, feel free to move or zap if needed.
Posts.Title: The "rubber band" stress technique

Posts.Content: Found this... http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer829.php
Posts.Title: Calculator - Recurrence after curative options exhausted

Posts.Content: Is there a calculator that estimates times until things like metastasizing disease and death after a recurrence of prostate cancer after all curative options had been exhausted?
Posts.Title: Calculator - Recurrence after curative options exhausted

Posts.Content: Is Hospice involved? In our area they are known to do a better job of keeping patients comfortable than the doctors! Also, it may not really matter how close to end of life you believe your father may be - they will often step in even when people feel they have and want some time yet. My father died of prostate cancer and we wish we had involved them earlier. My prayers and sympathy for this situation.
Posts.Title: chemo#2 - passed stool in his sleep, feeling very tired - please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by nrhk There is no hospice involved. He was doing just fine on chemo, walking about 60 mins/day and doing some exercises and eating well....until this symptom showed up. Glad to hear he was doing pretty well until this. Apologies if I seemed insensitive or presumptuous.

Posts.Content: I am through 27 of 38 salvage EBRT's. Additional images were taken and will be reviewed by the radiation oncologist. Anyway, they said for this "boost" they would be delivering the same total amount of radiation at each treatment, but it would be confined to more limited areas. To my knowledge my disease was organ confined on the lab report and there wasn't a specific target like a positive margin. Is this unusual? Anyone had a similar experience?
Posts.Signature: To the best of my recollection... Diagnosed fall 2000, age 42, PSA 10 Gleason 6 Surgery University of Michigan December 2000, Martin Sanda, lab report clean in all respects, organ confined, Gleason upgraded to 7 PSA 0.2 or less through 2010 (standard instructed by surgeon), gap in PSA testing until 2015, came in at 2.88. (I know, I know). Currently undergoing EBRT Dec 2015 and Jan 2016 with 2 years of adjunctive hormone therapy
Posts.Title: Radiation "Boost"

Posts.Content: San Antonio, October 19, 2015  Prostate cancer patients who face recurrence after radical prostatectomy (RP) have better overall survival rates with a combination of salvage radiation therapy (RT) and 24 months of anti-androgen therapy (AAT) than with RT alone, according to research presented today at the American Society for Radiation Oncologys (ASTROs) 57th Annual Meeting... https://www.astro.org/News-and-Media...pley_AM15.aspx
Posts.Title: 24 months of ADT during and after radiation improves long-term overall survival

Posts.Content: Congrats. BTW, am I reading wrong? It looks like your PSA nearly tripled in the three months before surgery? 3/2015 1.7 6/2015. 4.8 9/2015 RALP (age 45)
Posts.Title: 3 months after da Vinci...first post op PSA

Posts.Content: Is a long series of EBRT treatments to the prostate bed ever appropriate when the disease is likely systemic yet in a relatively early stage, perhaps to "de-bulk" the cancer? I had always thought this type of EBRT therapy was only intended to be curative, but thought I've seen some cases discussed here where the disease is recently diagnosed and the circumstances make it seem likely systemic, yet this type of EBRT is given and followed up with hormone therapy, as opposed to going straight to HT alone.
Posts.Title: EBRT to prostate bed when disease is likely systemic

Posts.Content: Congrats. BTW, am I reading wrong? It looks like your PSA nearly tripled in the three months before surgery? 3/2015 1.7 6/2015. 4.8 9/2015 RALP (age 45)
Posts.Title: 3 months after da Vinci...first post op PSA

Posts.Content: My initial reaction? Quality of life. I can understand wanting to go after it relatively early, but get a sense of the PSADT maybe see how long it can be controlled with intermittent hormone therapy and hit it at perhaps 5.0, not 0.1.
Posts.Title: "Early" Chemo - how early?

Posts.Content: But I'm talking about how early to start chemo after all curative treatments have failed and there is a recurrence ... not as adjunctive with primary treatments, which seems to be what you are referring to.
Posts.Title: "Early" Chemo - how early?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter I hope your treatment will be successful so you do not have to face this dilemma. Since it is hypothetical, let me give you a hypothetical answer based on logic: I assumed there are a lot of similarities between different types of cancer, especially between breast cancer and prostate cancer. I am not arguing about non aggressive prostate cancer where AS seemed to be fine. I am talking about prostate cancer that are aggressive, so similar to typical breast cancers. Here are a few recent researches on delaying treatment and delaying chemo for breast cancer: http://www.mdanderson.org/newsroom/n...-negative.html http://archsurg.jamanetwork.com/arti...icleid=1681805 http://journal.frontiersin.org/artic...014.00087/full It essentially said delaying treatment and chemo reduced survival. I often stayed up at night think about "what if's". My conclusion, for me anyway was to throw everything at it as early as possible and with as many modalities as my body could take because a., multiple modalities reduced the chance of mutation and b., earlier gets the cancer before drug resistance or distant met. As for QOL, being cancer free >> on hormone for the rest of my life, even if I have to endure up six months of chemo and two years of hormone. I don't know if the logic makes any sense but as you said it is hypothetical. These are legitimate topics to talk over with your oncologists to see what their views are so in case you have to pull the trigger you have a plan. Regards, A fair and reasonable response. On the other hand, if IHT could control the cancer and keep it 5.0 or lower for five, eight, ten years....is there enough advantage and evidence in terms of earlier intervention with chemo and complete hormone block that it's worth that? And would it be useful to perhaps establish a PSA doubling rate by tracking it after recurrence to determine just how agressive it might be? I don't know the answers but there are certainly two sides worth considering.
Posts.Title: "Early" Chemo - how early?

Posts.Content: I am currently EBRT along with 24 months of hormone block. I am at a high risk of recurrence and am an otherwise heathy 57 year old. I have heard about the studies indicating "early" chemo can be more effective. But it's my understanding these studies were done on men who had been recently diagnosed with "with bone metastases and clear radiological evidence of disease". Has chemo immediately after recurrence also been shown to be effective?
Posts.Title: "Early" Chemo - how early?

Posts.Content: Sorry for the confusion I've caused! My current situation is salvage radiation, with high risk of recurrence. Based on that study, the radiation oncologist recommended two years HT in addition to the radiation - I assume to increase the chances of the radiation being successful. This thread is hypothetical - should my slavage radiation fail and curitive options are exhausted, how early should chemo start?
Posts.Title: "Early" Chemo - how early?
